title: Theory CS Club, ISI Kolkata
text:
Speaker: Akanksha Das, BStat 3rd

This talk introduces Latent Surface Attribution, a novel attribution framework inspired by the Nambu–Goto action from string theory. Instead of tracing feature importance along a single path, it constructs a local 2D surface in latent space around the input of interest and measures how the model’s gradient flows through this surface. The decoder-induced metric captures how latent directions expand or distort in input space, enabling geometrically meaningful attribution. This approach avoids reliance on arbitrary baselines, reduces pointwise noise by aggregating model sensitivity over a continuous neighborhood, and satisfies most standard axioms of attribution methods. Experimental evaluations on vision models demonstrate improved stability and competitive performance over manifold-based path attribution techniques.



When: 12th December 2025,


Where: Google Meet link


Slides: Will be uploaded after the session.






Speaker: Arikith Roy Chowdhury, Bstat 3rd


Poset games are impartial combinatorial games played on partially ordered sets, where players alternately remove an element along with everything greater than it in the order. Despite their simple rules, these games hide deep computational complexity—the fundamental question of determining the winning player has been shown to be PSPACE-complete. This talk provides an introduction to the structure and theory of poset games, illustrating classical results such as memoryless optimal strategies in specific subclasses, and reductions connecting poset games to other well-studied complexity problems.

Introduction to Complexity Theory and Turing Machines


Speaker: Rudrayan Kundu, MStat 1st

In this talk we give a brief introduction to the models of computation and Turing Machines and how that does not matter. We define the classes P and NP based on our definition of deterministic turing machines.

On Real Zeros of Dense and Sparse Random Polynomials


Speaker: Arikith Roy Chowdhury, BStat 3rd

The expected number of real zeros of random polynomials has been a subject of great interest due to its connections with algebraic as well as geometric complexity theory. In this talk we will be exploring the Kac’s integral formula for dense random polynomials and see it’s derivation by Edelman-Kostlan. Thereafter we will see Bürgisser’s upper bound for k-sparse polynomials and a very recent improvement of the bound, making it tight. We will also try to get glimpses into The Real Tau Conjecture and its implications along with recent developments and possible research directions.

Real Tau true on average






The Real Tau Conjecture is True in Average


Speaker: Arikith Roy Chowdhury, BStat 3rd

The Real Tau Conjecture is one of those big open problems which, if proven true, have really significant implications in complexity theory and computer science. Although the problem remains opens in general, very recently Burgisser and Briquel were able to show that the conjecture holds true in the average case for random polynomials given by ΣΠΣΠ depth-4 arithmetic circuits. In this talk we will see a sketch of their proof using Rice’s formula and Rice inequality from the theory of random fields along with techniques from multivariate calculus and differential topology. Thereafter we plan to have a philosophical discussion regarding the interpretation of this result and further research directions.

title: Sharper intuitions, stronger foundations, shared curiosity
text:
Theory CS Club · ISI Kolkata


Sharper intuitions, stronger foundations, shared curiosity

The Theory CS Club is a student-led initiative at ISI Kolkata for everyone interested in algorithms, complexity theory, automata, combinatorics, logic, and related areas. We read papers, solve problems together, and try to understand the mathematical foundations of computation.


Our motto

To build a small but serious community where people can learn, question, and work on ideas in theoretical computer science together.






Stay Connected


Reach out if you want to join the club, suggest a talk, or share resources.



Email:  theorycsclub.isi@example.com 


YouTube:  Our YouTube channel 


WhatsApp group:  Join the WhatsApp group 



Replace these links with the actual club email, YouTube channel, and WhatsApp invite. New members are always welcome.






What we do


Reading groups, blackboard talks, problem sessions, and informal discussions on core topics in theoretical CS and related mathematics.




Talks


We regularly host short talks by students on topics they find interesting. Slides, notes, and recordings are archived on the Talks page.

See talks →



How to join


Just come to a session, or send us an email / message on the WhatsApp group. No background is “too little” as long as you’re curious.
